facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1965 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 50 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 15, 1965 of Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 917 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 15, 1965 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revi- sion Application No. 917 of 1964.

facts.text: Nine accused in trial court, all acquitted except accused Nos. 1 and 2 who are appellants 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: In the trial companyrt there were as many as nine accused. All the accused excepting accused Nos. 1 and 2 who are appellants 1 and 2 respectively in this Court, were, acquitted.

facts.text: Acquitted third accused was owner of jeep bearing registration No. BYF 5448. Accused No. 2 is his father. They are residents of Malshiras.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is as follows The acquitted third ac- cused was the owner of the jeep bearing registration No. BYF 5448. Accused ,No. 2 is his father. They are the residents of Malshiras.

facts.text: On October 27, 1962, appellants along with PW Rambhau Bhombe and one other went in the jeep to Phaltan (33 miles from Malshiras), then to Rajale (7 miles from Phaltan), back to Phaltan, to Malegaon, stayed night at Malegaon.

anchor.surface_text: On October 27, 1962, the appellants along with PW Rambhau Bhombe and one other, went in the jeep in question first to Phaltan which is about 33 miles away from Malshiras, from there to Rajale about seven miles away from Phaltan. From Rajale they returned to Phaltan and from there to Malegaon. They stayed for the night at Malegaon.

facts.text: Next day after October 27, 1962, they returned to Phaltan and finally to Malshiras.

anchor.surface_text: Next day they returned to Phaltan and finally to Malshiras. During all this time, appellant No. 1 was driving the jeep.

facts.text: Appellant No. 1 was driving the jeep during all this time.

anchor.surface_text: During all this time, appellant No. 1 was driving the jeep. On the way from Phaltan to Malshiras, about a mile and a half from Phaltan, the jeep struck one Bapu Babaji Bhiwarkar

facts.text: On the way from Phaltan to Malshiras, about a mile and a half from Phaltan, the jeep struck Bapu Babaji Bhiwarkar, resulting in serious injuries.

anchor.surface_text: On the way from Phaltan to Malshiras, about a mile and a half from Phaltan, the jeep struck one Bapu Babaji Bhiwarkar, as a result of which he sustained serious injuries.

facts.text: Appellants put injured Bapu Babaji Bhiwarkar in jeep, brought to Phaltan, approached PW Dr. Karwa for medical aid, but refused as medico-legal case, advised to go to Government Dispensary.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants put the injured person in the jeep and brought back the jeep to Phaltan where they approached PW Dr. Karwa for medical aid, but Dr. Karwa refused to treat the injured as it was a medico-legal case. He asked them to go to Government Dispensary.

facts.text: Appellants drove straight to Malshiras instead of Government Dispensary; injured died on the way; at Malshiras, appellants cremated the dead body.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants instead of going to the Government Dispensary, drove straight to Malshiras. On the way the injured died. At Malshiras the appellants cremated his dead body.

facts.text: At the time of the incident, first appellant had only a learner's licence and no person having valid licence was by his side.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the incident, the first appellant had only a learners licence and numberperson having a valid licence for driving was by his side.

facts.text: Courts below accepted the above facts.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrts below have accepted the above facts and on the basis of those facts, the trial companyrt companyvicted the appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC

facts.text: Trial court convicted appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC, s. 3 read with s. 112 of Motor Vehicles Act, and s. 89 of the same Act.

anchor.surface_text: the trial companyrt companyvicted the appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC, s. 3 read with s. 112 of the Motor Vehicles Act and under s. 89 of the same Act.

facts.text: Trial court convicted second appellant under s. 201 IPC, s. 5 as well as s. 89 of Motor Vehicles Act.

anchor.surface_text: It companyvicted the second appellant under s. 201 IPC, s. -5 as well as under s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act.

facts.text: Convictions affirmed by Sessions Judge of Satara in appeal and by High Court in revision.

anchor.surface_text: These companyvictions were affirmed by the learned Sessions Judge of Satara in appeal and by the High Court in revision.

facts.text: Supreme Court: Conviction of first appellant under Motor Vehicles Act not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of the first appellant under the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act was number challenged before us

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside conviction of second appellant under s.5 and s.89 MV Act as he was not owner or in charge of jeep.

anchor.surface_text: but we fail to see how the second appellant companyld have been companyvicted either under s. 5 or under s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act. In companyvicting him under those provisions, the companyrts below appear to have overlooked the fact that he was number the owner of the jeep.

facts.text: No evidence to show how the accident took place; no witnesses to establish rash and negligent driving by accused No.1.

anchor.surface_text: On the material on record it is number possible to find out under what circumstances the accident took place. The High Court in its judgment specifically says that There are numberwitnesses whose evidence can establish rash and negligent driving on the part of accused No. 1.

facts.text: Accused No.1 had only learner's licence at material time; not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: We may go further and say that there is absolutely numberevidence to show that the accused was responsible for the accident. ... It is however, a fact companyclusively established and number disputed before me that the accused No. 1 had only a learners licence at the material time.

facts.text: No suggestion that accused No.2 held driving licence to act as trainer; no trainer by side of accused No.1.

anchor.surface_text: It is number even suggested before me that accused No. 2 held a driving licence so that he companyld act as a trainer for accused No. 1. In fact, there is numbersuggestion by the defence that there was a trainer by the side of accused No. 1.

facts.text: PW Shankar Burmule saw accused No.1 driving for about six months to a year.

anchor.surface_text: From the prosecution evidence itself it is clear that he drove the jeep to various places on October 27, 1962. Then there was the evidence of PW Shankar Burmule, showing that he had seen accused No. 1 driving for about six months to a year.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquits appellant No.1 under s.304A IPC as no proof that rash/negligent act caused death; no proximate cause established.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant companyld have been held guilty under s. 304A IPC. We accordingly allow his appeal and acquit him of that offence.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquits second appellant under s.201 IPC as depends on conviction under 304A.

anchor.surface_text: From that finding, it follows that the second appellant companyld number have been companyvicted under s. 201 IPC. In the result, the second appellants appeal is allowed in full and he is acquitted of all the charges.

anchor.surface_text: licence. The question for companysi- deration, therefore, is whether driving a jeep on a public road by a person, who does number know driving and is companysequently unable to companytrol the vehicle, is a rash and negligent act as companytemplated by Section 304A IPC. The companyrt answered that question in these words The very fact

issues.text: whether the rash or negligent act of accused was the proximate cause of the death

anchor.surface_text: requirements of this section are that the death of any person must have been caused by the accused by doing any rash or negligent act. In other words, there must be proof that the rash or negligent act of accused was the proximate cause of the death. There must be direct nexus between the death -of

arguments.claim: Driving a vehicle on public road with only learner's licence without trainer violates Rule 16 Bombay MV Rules and constitutes rash and negligent act under s.304A IPC causing death

anchor.surface_text: The court answered that question in these words The very fact that the person concerned holds only a learners licence, in my opinion, necessarily implies that he does not know driving and must be assumed to be incapable of controlling the vehicle. If a person who does not know driving and is consequently not able to control a car or a vehicle, chooses to drive a car or a vehicle on a public road without complying with the requirements of Rule 16 of Bombay Motor Vehicles Rules, he obviously does an act, which can be said to be rash and negligent, as contemplated by Sec. 304A IPC. It is negligent because he does not take the necessary care of having a trainer by his side.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: son, who does number know driving and is companysequently unable to companytrol the vehicle, is a rash and negligent act as companytemplated by Sectio

arguments.court_reasoning: Even if negligent, prosecution must prove it was proximate cause of death; no evidence of how accident occurred or accused's responsibility

arguments.claim: No evidence on record to determine circumstances of accident or establish rash/negligent driving by accused No.1 or his responsibility for accident

anchor.surface_text: On the material on record it is not possible to find out under what circumstances the accident took place. The High Court in its judgment specifically says that There are no witnesses whose evidence can establish rash and negligent driving on the part of accused No. 1. We may go further and say that there is absolutely no evidence to show that the accused was responsible for the accident.

arguments.claim: Accused No.1 had only learner's licence, no trainer by side, implying incapable of controlling vehicle, making driving rash/negligent per se

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution has not produced any evidence to show as to how the accident took place. ... It is however, a fact conclusively established and not disputed before me that the accused No. 1 had only a learners licence at the material time. It is not even suggested before me that accused No. 2 held a driving licence so that he could act as a trainer for accused No. 1.

arguments.claim: PW Shankar Burmule's evidence of accused No.1's driving experience unreliable as he is relation of accused No.2 and learner's licence indicates no experience

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the High Court discarded his evidence with these observations In the present case, Mr. Jahagirdar relies on the evidence of Shankar Burmule... the admitted fact that at the material time accused No. 1 held only a learners licence itself indicates that no importance can be attached to the abovesaid statement of Shankar Burmule.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: n evidence itself it is clear that he drove the jeep to various places on October 27, 1962. Then there was the evidence of PW Shankar Burmule, showing

arguments.court_reasoning: Improper appreciation; evidence material and uncontradicted; no presumption learner's licence means no driving knowledge; prior driving proved

arguments.claim: No presumption that holder of learner's licence lacks driving knowledge; prosecution evidence shows accused drove jeep previous day to various places proving he knew driving

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the learned Judge we think this was not the proper way of appreciating evidence. Conclusions must be based on the evidence on record. PW Shankar Burmule has given material evidence against the accused. ... The prosecution evidence that appellant No. 1 had driven the jeep to various places on the day previous to the occurrence is a proof of the fact that he knew driving.

arguments.claim: To convict under s.201 IPC, must prove offence committed, not mere suspicion; conviction under s.304A IPC essential prerequisite

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the appellant No. 2 under s. 201 IPC depends on the sustainability of the conviction of appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC. ... The proof of the commission of an offence is an essential requisite for bringing home the offence under s. 201 IPC-see the decision of this Court in Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab.

arguments.claim: Second appellant cannot be convicted under s.5 or s.89 Motor Vehicles Act as he was neither owner nor in charge of jeep

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the first appellant under the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act was not challenged before us, but we fail to see how the second appellant could have been convicted either under s. 5 or under s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act. In convicting him under those provisions, the courts below appear to have overlooked the fact that he was not the owner of the jeep. Nor was there any proof that he was in charge of the jeep.

arguments.claim: Under s.304A IPC, rash/negligent act must be proximate/direct cause of death (causa causans, not sine qua non); mere rash act insufficient without proof of causation

anchor.surface_text: There must be proof that the rash or negligent act of accused was the proximate cause of the death. There must be direct nexus between the death of a person and the rash or negligent act of the accused. ... Dealing with the scope of S. 304A IPC, Sir Lawrence Jenkins observed in Emperor v. Omkar Rampratap To impose criminal liability under S. 304A, Indian Penal Code, it is necessary that the death should have been the direct result of a rash and negligent act of the accused, and that act must be the proximate and efficient cause without the intervention of anothers negligence.

arguments.claim: Rash/negligent act of allowing burners near flammables not proximate cause of fire/deaths in Kurban Hussein case; analogous here where no proof negligent driving caused accident

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 304A IPC came to be considered by this Court in Kurban Hussein Mohammedali Rangwalla v. State of Maharashtra. In our opinion, the ratio of that decision governs the facts of the present case. ... what s. 304A requires is causing of death by doing any rash or negligent act and this means that death must be the direct or proximate result of the rash or negligent act.

arguments.claim: Juggankhan case distinguishable as there rash/negligent act conclusively proved as cause of death, unlike here
Facts found by lower courts insufficient to convict appellants under s.304A, s.201 IPC and relevant MV Act provisions

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay in criminal revision application No. 917/64, the question that arises for decision is whether on the facts found by the courts below, the appellants were properly held to be guilty of all or any of the offences for which they have been convicted.

holdings.text: The second appellant could not have been convicted under s. 5 or s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act as he was not the owner of the jeep nor was there proof that he was in charge of it

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the first appellant under the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act was not challenged before us, but we fail to see how the second appellant could have been convicted either under s. 5 or under s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act. In convicting him under those provisions, the courts below appear to have overlooked the fact that he was not the owner of the jeep.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Courts below overlooked that appellant 2 was not owner; no evidence he was in charge, so provisions inapplicable

holdings.text: To convict under s. 201 IPC, prosecution must prove an offence was committed, not merely suspicion; conviction under s. 304A IPC is prerequisite

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the appellant No. 2 under s. 201 IPC depends on the sustainability of the conviction of appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC. If appellant No. 1 was rightly convicted under that provision, the conviction of appellant No. 2 under s. 201 IPC on the facts found cannot be challenged. But on the other hand, if the conviction of appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC cannot be sustained, then, the second appellants conviction under s. 201 IPC will have to be set aside, because to establish the charge under s. 201, the prosecution must first prove that an offence had been committed not merely a suspicion that it might have been committed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proof of offence commission essential, applying Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab

holdings.text: Under s. 304A IPC, rash or negligent act must be the proximate and direct cause (causa causans) of death; mere rash/negligent act insufficient without proof of nexus

anchor.surface_text: There must be proof that the rash or negligent act of accused was the proximate cause of the death. There must be direct nexus between the death of a person and the rash or negligent act of the accused. As mentioned earlier there is no evidence to show that it was rash or the negligent act of the accused that caused the death of the deceased. ... what s. 304A requires is causing of death by doing any rash or negligent act and this means that death must be the direct or proximate result of the rash or negligent act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying textual interpretation of s.304A, precedents Emperor v. Omkar Rampratap (proximate cause required), Kurban Hussein (analogy: negligent act not direct cause); distinguishing Juggankhan (causation proved there)

holdings.text: Appellant No. 1 not guilty under s. 304A IPC as no evidence that his driving was rash/negligent or proximate cause of death

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the High Court was right in its conclusion that appellant No. 1 had not acquired sufficient proficiency in driving therefore he was guilty of a rash or negligent act in driving the jeep that by itself is not sufficient to convict him under s. 304A IPC. The prosecution must go further and prove that it was that rash or negligent act of his that caused the death of the deceased. ... For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the courts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could have been held guilty under s. 304A IPC. We accordingly allow his appeal and acquit him of that offence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of accident circumstances, responsibility, or causation despite learner's licence; prosecution evidence shows prior safe driving proficiency; no presumption of incompetence from licence

holdings.text: Appellants not properly held guilty of offences on facts found by courts below

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay in criminal revision application No. 917/64, the question that arises for decision is whether on the facts found by the courts below, the appellants were properly held to be guilty of all or any of the offences for which they have been convicted.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts accepted but insufficient for any conviction under IPC or MV Act provisions due to lack of proof of rashness, causation, ownership/charge

holdings.text: Second appellant acquitted under s. 201 IPC as depends on invalid s. 304A conviction

anchor.surface_text: From that finding, it follows that the second appellant could not have been convicted under s. 201 IPC. In the result, the second appellants appeal is allowed in full and he is acquitted of all the charges.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.201 conviction falls with acquittal under s.304A as no proved offence to screen

holdings.text: No presumption that holder of learner's licence lacks driving knowledge; proficiency proved by prior driving evidence

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the learned Judge we think this was not the proper way of appreciating evidence. Conclusions must be based on the evidence on record. PW Shankar Burmule has given material evidence against the accused. ... There is no presumption in law that a person who possesses only a learners licence or possesses no licence at all does not know driving. ... The prosecution evidence that appellant No. 1 had driven the jeep to various places on the day previous to the occurrence is a proof of the fact that he knew driving.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejecting lower court inference; crediting uncontradicted PW evidence and prior incident driving; evidence appreciation principles

precedents.citation: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: see the decision of this Court in Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab  1 . Therefore the principal question for decision is whether on the facts found, appellant No. 1 was rightly convicted under s. 304A IPC.

precedents.case_name: Palvinder Kaur v. State of Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: proof of the commission of an offence is an essential requisite for bringing home the offence under s. 201 IPC

anchor.surface_text: observed in Emperor v. Omkar Rampratap 1  To impose criminal liability under S. 304A, Indian Penal Code, it is necessary that the death should have been the direct result of a rash and negligent act of the accused, and that act must be the proximate and efficient cause without the intervention of anothers negligence. It must be the cause causans, it is not enough that it may have been the cause sine qua non.

precedents.cited_proposition: To impose criminal liability under S. 304A, Indian Penal Code, it is necessary that the death should have been the direct result of a rash and negligent act of the accused, and that act must be the proximate and efficient cause without the intervention of anothers negligence. It must be the cause causans, it is not enough that it may have been the cause sine qua non.
precedents.cited_holding: death should have been the direct result of a rash and negligent act... causa causans not sine qua non

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 304A IPC came to be considered by this Court in Kurban Hussein Mohammedali Rangwalla v. State of Maharashtra 2 . In our opinion, the ratio of that decision governs the facts of the present case.

precedents.case_name: Kurban Hussein Mohammedali Rangwalla v. State of Maharashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: death must be the direct or proximate result of the rash or negligent act
precedents.cited_holding: the mere fact that the appellant allowed the burners to be used... would not be enough... direct and proximate cause of the fire... was the act of one of the workmen

precedents.cited_proposition: rash or negligent act of the accused was the cause of the death

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the first appellant under the provisions of the Motor Vehicles Act was not challenged before us, but we fail to see how the second appellant could have been convicted either under s. 5 or under s. 89 of the Motor Vehicles Act. In convicting him under those provisions, the courts below appear to have overlooked the fact that he was not the owner of the jeep.
For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could

anchor.surface_text: The conviction of the appellant No. 2 under s. 201 IPC depends on the sustainability of the conviction of appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC. If appellant No. 1 was rightly convicted under that provision, the conviction of appellant No. 2 under s. 201 IPC on the facts found cannot be challenged. But on the other hand, if the conviction of appellant No. 1 under s. 304A IPC cannot be sustained, then, the second appellants conviction under s. 201 IPC will have to be set aside, because to establish the charge under s. 201, the prosecution must first prove that an offence had been committed not merely a suspicion that it might have been committed
For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could

anchor.surface_text: There must be proof that the rash or negligent act of accused was the proximate cause of the death. There must be direct nexus between the death of a person and the rash or negligent act of the accused. As mentioned earlier there is no evidence to show that it was rash or the negligent act of the accused that caused the death of the deceased. ... what s. 304A requires is causing of death by doing any rash or negligent act and this means that death must be the direct or proximate result of the rash or negligent act.
For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the High Court was right in its conclusion that appellant No. 1 had not acquired sufficient proficiency in driving therefore he was guilty of a rash or negligent act in driving the jeep that by itself is not sufficient to convict him under s. 304A IPC. The prosecution must go further and prove that it was that rash or negligent act of his that caused the death of the deceased. ... For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the courts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could have been held guilty under s. 304A IPC. We accordingly allow his appeal and acquit him of that offence.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by special leave against the judgment of the High Court of Bombay in criminal revision application No. 917/64, the question that arises for decision is whether on the facts found by the courts below, the appellants were properly held to be guilty of all or any of the offences for which they have been convicted.
For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could

From that finding, it follows that the second appellant could not have been convicted under s. 201 IPC. In the result, the second appellants appeal is allowed in full and he is acquitted of all the charges.

anchor.surface_text: With respect to the learned Judge we think this was not the proper way of appreciating evidence. Conclusions must be based on the evidence on record. PW Shankar Burmule has given material evidence against the accused. ... There is no presumption in law that a person who possesses only a learners licence or possesses no licence at all does not know driving. ... The prosecution evidence that appellant No. 1 had driven the jeep to various places on the day previous to the occurrence is a proof of the fact that he knew driving.
For the reasons mentioned above, we are unable to agree with the companyrts below that on the basis of the facts found by them the first appellant could
